utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You know, downward-facing dog comes from the Sanskrit phrase adho mukha shvanasana.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, that’s beautiful. What does it mean?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Downward-facing dog.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, I guess they don’t have Sanskrit for butts up and heads down.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, we wrote the Kama Sutra. If it involves butts, there’s a word for it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I thought we were getting breakfast before work.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, right, sorry.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s my fault. I asked Penny to do yoga with me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: If you want, I can get ready in five minutes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s cute that you think that. Don’t worry about it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, can I ask you a favour? Would you mind taking Cinnamon for a walk?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure. You’re living here for free, I guess I owe you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Bye, Cinnamon. Be a good girl.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, bye, sweetie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, bye, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, and tree pose.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, she’s done.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Things have been going really well with the infinite resistance gyroscope.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That’s great. How so?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, the project is classified. I can’t tell you. Oh, I suppose I could redact the classified parts. All right, um, I came up with an elegant solution to the I used the And then I And that did it. Wow, I wonder what they’re redacting.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Why don’t you ask me what I’m working on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, very well. What have you been working on? And feel free to honk during the boring parts.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m doing some experiments to show that the signal to move a muscle occurs before you know you even decided to move it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So you’re attempting to pinpoint where consciousness resides in the brain.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Yes, I’m trying to figure out to the nanometer and the attosecond, precisely where and when an event of awareness takes place.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, what do you know? Here I was, waiting to be bored with biology, and instead you tickle my intellectual fancy. Which, unlike my body, is an okay place to tickle.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You know, when I was six, I wanted to marry the gorilla from Good Night, Gorilla. Maybe I was onto something.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Gentlemen, the most interesting thing just happened with this spoon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Unless it was singing Be Our Guest, I doubt it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I picked it up without thinking about it. Which raises a neuroscientific question, when did I decide to pick it up?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: The bigger question is, what are you gonna eat with that spoon? You didn’t get any food.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He does raise an interesting point.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy is studying the time lag between intent and awareness, and I realized that applies to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics. Now, I recognize there will be a time lag between me saying that and you Googling what it means, so I’ll wait.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I understand it, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, me, too.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I spaced. Are we still talking about the spoon?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s nice to see you taking an interest in Amy’s work.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, don’t get me wrong. Neurobiology’s nothing more than the science of gray squishy stuff. But, you know, when it connects to physics, gas up the Ford, Martha, we’re going for a drive.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So did you confront Jennifer?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, I was going to, but she called in sick. And guess who else called in sick.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Paul.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Paul.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Who’s Paul?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, you met him at the office Christmas party. He’s married to Nancy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, sure. Wait, Nancy?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I bet Jennifer gets a promotion out of this, which is so unfair because I work twice as hard as she does.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t worry, Jerry won’t be fooled by that type of behaviour.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Jerry?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It didn’t work for Randy, it didn’t work for Tina, it sure as hell isn’t gonna work for Jennifer.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, I hope not. I just hate when people play those kinds of games.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Tina?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: With your sales record, you have nothing to worry about.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I went to your office Christmas party?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You know, I like harp lessons, but I’m thinking of switching to elevator repair lessons. What are you working on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was thinking about your experiment on the neuroscience of decision making, and I realized, if we connect it to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics, we have a chance to disprove the role of consciousness in the Copenhagen Interpretation.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Wait, are you saying if we combine my experiment with your calculations, we can determine the precise moment in time when the wave function collapses?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It could be the most inspired combination since I mixed red Icee into my blue Icee. It was like drinking two sevenths of the rainbow.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, this is really interesting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, and this one won’t stain my teeth purple.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You know, we’ve never collaborated professionally before. Are you worried it might affect our relationship?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That is a valid point. Perhaps we should establish some ground rules.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, that would make me feel better.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, let’s start right now. Uh, rule number one, no using sexuality to get your way.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That’s a ridiculous rule.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is it?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, how is that?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I can actually feel the toxins being pulled out of my skin.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, this is a moisturizing mask.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, well, then I can actually feel the moisture going into my skin.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, I hope you don’t mind, I used a little of your eye cream last night.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I thought someone looked brighter and tighter.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’d still like to know who Jerry is.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Don’t worry about it. Hey, after this, how about we all go out and do something together?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That would be great. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You want to go shopping?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ooh, yes. Fun.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Or we could do something we’ll all enjoy, like play a board game.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe I’ve made some progress on our ground rules.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, good. What are they?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, uh, number one, in matters of physics, I have the final say. In matters of neuroscience, you have the final say. Unless I disagree. Oh, here. Number two, when we publish,

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Can I see that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, of course. I’ll get that back. Like all my underwear, that notebook says Property of Sheldon Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, if we’re gonna have ground rules, I’ll tell you the first ground rule. I make the ground rules.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’d write that down, but I can’t now, can I?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I mean, they didn’t say anything, but I just kind of felt like I was being a weird third wheel.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Huh, so you can tell what that feels like. Interesting.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Anyway, I figured I can hang out with my friends and have fun, too.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, if your idea of fun is riding in a minivan to Target for diapers, things are about to get nuts.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, it’s just nice to be with people who are happy to have me around. Isn’t that right, Halley?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, at least someone had the courage to say it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you, you are a good citizen. Told you. Go ahead, throw my underwear out the window. Same thing’s gonna happen.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Terrific. Do you want to hear our new set of ground rules?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fire away.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Number one, we’re on the same team, we’re not in competition.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s smart, because Sheldon 1, Amy 0.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Number two, disagreements can happen politely. There’s no need to call an idea stupid.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Aw, someone drew a penis in it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Are you listening?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry, go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Number three, to avoid getting frustrated, we take built-in breaks and reward our successes with a small treat.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh, that sounds fun. Now, we’re talking about real treats, right? Not Bible verses like my mother used to give me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Whatever you want. So, shall we get to work?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Biology and physics coming together, this is like the peanut butter cup of the mind. Oh, I know what I want my treat to be.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Wow. Look at that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, this is remarkable.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: So we’re agreed, it’s complete garbage.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: By the way, your name can go first.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I mean, I’m glad they’re getting along, but it’s starting to make me uncomfortable.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, are you worried he’s like another man in her life?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: A little, until I saw them in matching tops.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Nice. 174 diapers. That ought to get us to Wednesday.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, have you talked to them about it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, what am I supposed to say, stop having fun without me?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: This one says that every time I go out. See? I listen to you.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Look, Raj just gets along with women.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I know, but he was my friend first. It’s like she’s stealing him and they’re just having the best time doing all their dumb girly stuff together.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You sure you don’t fit in? You sound like a catty bitch to me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I don’t know where we went wrong.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, the math is so inelegant. I’m not even sure it makes sense.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, don’t give up. Maybe we can fix it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can you stop breathing so loud? I can hear your nose whistling.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I can hear your face talking, so we’re even.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, either blow your nose or teach it to play Camptown Races.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Fine. Fine. You want me to blow my nose? Here, I’ll blow it. Better?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, I can still hear it. Oh, wait, that’s me. Never mind, it’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You know, you’re exhausting. I knew working together was a bad idea.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hold on. I see what’s wrong here. We did the propagation only to the occipital lobe, not to the prefrontal cortex.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That would mean that this delayed parameter should be increased 250 milliseconds.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that is much better. Yeah, boy, if good ideas came out of your brain the way mucus comes out of your nose, we’d be in good shape.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Now, take a sip, swirl it around your mouth, and try to notice the flavours, the tannins, the textures. Well?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I probably should have spit out my gum first.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah. You know, the last couple of weeks have been pretty rough, but, uh, staying here with you guys has really helped take my mind off of it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm. Well, we’ve loved having you around. Right, sweetie? Leonard?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: When did he leave?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s rude.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, it’s nice to spend time with people who don’t talk about work like it’s some kind of soap opera.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Jennifer still trying to sleep her way to the top?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You should be happy someone wants to do the stuff with Penny you don’t want to.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yeah, I wish I had that with Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Wait. What? What do I make you do?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Let’s see, the magic store, the Doctor Who convention, the National Belt Buckle Collector’s meet and greet.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It said right there on the invitation, buckle up for fun. It’s not my fault you didn’t listen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sure I’m overreacting.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You’re entitled to feel how you feel. If you don’t like it, you should just talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t want to sound like a jealous baby.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, then maybe you shouldn’t talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I had a feeling you were using the wrong computational model, but I didn’t say anything ’cause you’re so sensitive.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Just because I am easily bothered by light, heat, sound, smell and the way birds look at me does not mean I’m sensitive.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, I wonder what kind of success we’d have if we defined measurement as the first moment that an action potential is seen by the visual cortex.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That is a daring and insightful solution.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We’re finally making progress. I wish we could do it without fighting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What if the fighting is the reason we’re making progress?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I suppose it’s conceivable that the hormones associated with our fight-or-flight response could be sharpening our cognitive processes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, if that’s the case, then your grandparents mumble and have bad posture.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: How dare you speak that way about my Grammy and hey, wait a second. Wait. Delta T could equal alpha sub-zero.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It seems we have a choice to make. Abandon all ground rules in the name of science, or give up collaborating for the sake of our relationship.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: There’s only one clear choice.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Science it is.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: No, you bonehead.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Name calling, that is perfect. Now, when I get to this equation here, really let me have it. You know? If it helps, I’m not the sharpest dresser.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Anyway, I know it’s silly, but since Raj moved in, I’ve been feeling a little left out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, sweetie, that’s crazy.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, no, Penny, don’t dismiss his feelings.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. I just feel…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hang on, I’m not saying that his feelings aren’t crazy. I just don’t want him to think that this isn’t a safe place.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, to be truthful…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, why wouldn’t this be a safe place? I mean, he’s surrounded by his wife and one of his best friends.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I don’t want to speak for Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. I…

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: But when you’re insecure, no amount of external validation can ever make you feel safe.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, you’re right. You know, you’re really sensitive about this kind of stuff.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m a good listener.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, Olsen twins…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, I mean, I’m sitting right here. You’re talking about my feelings and somehow leaving me out of the conversation.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m sorry. What did you want to say?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know, you pretty much covered it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Can you read them back?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Revised ground rule number one, we are on the same team, but it is a competition.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excellent. Excellent. And on a related point, you’re going down, punk.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Revised ground rule number two, there are definitely stupid questions, and those who ask them can be told so right to their stupid face.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I love that one.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Thanks, babe. Number three, fair topics for insult include educational pedigree, scientific field, intellectual prowess, and mamas.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, that list is strong. Like your mother’s urge to be promiscuous with sailors.
